ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: During this course, we learned how to conduct research in an academic setting that would serve as an insight to what our graduate degree and thesis project would be if we were to join the lab.
I got to choose a lab to join! I further honed my ability to do research--to plan experiments, analyze data, think thorough challenges, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A bit too short to complete a project. A bit too long for knowing the lab

I think one thing that can be improved are outlining the expectations of rotation students and faculty when bringing in a new student to rotate in the lab and how those expectations shift once you have joined the lab. I think also providing resources on how to improve on one's weaknesses before joining a lab would be very useful.
Strengths: Allows students to explore their research interests and interact with faculty and other PhD/Postdocs. Weaknesses: None.
strength- using large rooms for presentation weakness- talks were given after rotation decision so it was awkward if we didn't join the 3rd lab

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a critical course for any student intending to earn a PhD at Yale. I heartily recommend it to all.
